content: Rising procurement costs for Navy ships are a concern for Navy officials and Members of Congress. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that executing a 30-year Navy shipbuilding plan may require higher annual funding levels than currently planned. Constraints on ship-procurement funding have led to reduced ship procurement rates in recent years, causing concern about the future size of the Navy and shipyards. Some Members of Congress are concerned about reduced ship procurement rates and rising Navy ship procurement costs. Congress must decide how to address these issues, which could impact future Navy capabilities, funding requirements, and the shipbuilding industrial base. Options include increasing funding, changing budget allocation for Navy ships, and utilizing multiyear procurement. Options to address reduced ship procurement rates and rising Navy ship procurement costs include increasing annual Navy ship-procurement funding, changing budget allocation for Navy ships, utilizing multiyear procurement, changing acquisition strategy, reducing shipyard fixed overhead costs, improving operating efficiency of shipyards, building ships without some planned equipment, and building ships in foreign shipyards with lower construction costs.
